prompt:
MEMORY:Knowledge 18 Notes
11 May 2018 by Jace Benson

I was very lucky to get to go to Knowledge18 and before I leave I just want to write this down as to not forget it.

Of the labs, I attended I had no technical difficulty with the wifi or content. Others did, but somehow not me.

Below I'll go over the parts I think notable.

Things to keep in mind in general
If there are repeating classes the later ones will be better but the speaker may have lost their voice

Know the difference between the different types of events.

Breakouts are talks
Labs are step by step instruction with an instructor in the room to field questions and assist
Workshops are the same as labs but CreatorCon
Look up the content of the event. If it's not a current feature, it's probably a new feature and might be a "this will be nice but you don't get it for two releases"

Look up the presenters of the event. If it's a partner, be careful as it may be more of a success story of how some implementation or product they used was successful.

Registration
Looks like they used g2planet.com which this year was pretty poor in my opinion. Hard to tell what you had already selected until you tried to add an event to the agenda

Suggestions to improve - Use what you used for 2016's registration or make your own.

Mobile App
This was terrible. I literally wrote my schedule down each day as it was more convenient to do that. Thankfully none of my classes moved after I arrived.

Suggestions to improve - Don't provide a mobile app. It would have been easier and then we'd been complaining about the website.

Social Stuff
This was great. With the way, my rep helped us get around and with all the folks.

Labs
LAB1012 Manage Duplicate CIs Effortlessly to Keep Your CMDB Clean
This was an awesome lab. It showed a new feature that lets you merge and handle the remaining duplicate ci's and their relationships in a very flexible way.

Lab URL

On-demand Library
URL

CCW0194 Advanced Identification Engine for Discovery
This really was all about using the horizontal patterns to discover configuration items which in my case would have been great three weeks prior as I had to self-teach myself it. It did confirm that I did learn this properly. There's a great youtube video where they show how to do most of this.

Lab URL

On-demand Library URL

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R_49vxeGz78

LAB0272 Discovery & Service Mapping in a Cloud First World - PaaS/IaaS
Again this was a great session had I taken it three weeks prior. It did confirm I did learn the right topics and it focused on the Cloud Services Plugin v2.

Lab URL

On-demand Library URL

LAB0299 Threat Hunting, Awareness and Sharing with Security Operations
This was a nice overview of what the Secops application brings to ServiceNow. I thought of it to something akin to an overview of how GRC would work except you were guided along setting it up.

Lab URL

On-demand Library URL

CCW1088 -- Service Portal: Advanced Widget Development
This lab was great in that I learned about the directives and how you can use them and share them across widgets. I also learned about a different way to have widgets communicate to each other than the broadcast and emitted events.

Lab URL

On-demand Library URL

Labs I need to check out yet
CCW0343 Using Event Management to Monitor Your ServiceNow Instance Health

CCW0504 Agent Intelligence - Deployment Best Practices
Lab URL

On-demand Library URL

CCW0471 Test Driven Development with ServiceNow
Lab URL

CCW1224 Best Practices for Scripted REST APIs
Lab URL

On-demand Library URL

CCW0682 Advanced Scripting and JSON
Lab URL

On-demand Library URL

CCW1358 Advanced Techniques for Creating High Usability Chatbot Conversations
Lab URL

Abbreviations and acronyms are shortened forms of words or phrases. An abbreviation is typically a shortened form of words used to represent the whole (such as Dr. or Prof.) while an acronym contains a set of initial letters from a phrase that usually form another word (such as radar or scuba).

Like me, you probably have seen many refer to ServiceNow as "Snow" or "SN".

Is there a right way to shorten ServiceNow?

As much as I want to say one way is right, and the other is wrong, by the results of the survey, really we should just use the full name.

What do you use when referring to ServiceNow, let me know in the comments or reply to the survey and why.

prompt:
MEMORY:Terminology and Wording
19 Sep 2019 by Jace Benson

I took this from, Hi's styleguide as I don't trust anyone to keep anything online. So this is just a local copy with opinions about word choices.

Note: Consider consulting with a technical writer before you commit UI text. Tech writers can help with clarity and consistency of UI text.

Avoid Using "Please"
Using "please" is unnecessary, unless you are asking the user to do something that is inconvenient or a result of a system error.

Do	Do not
Select custom application	Please Select a custom application
Error encountered while executing the selected rules. Please contact system administrator for further assistance	Error encountered while executing the selected rules. Contact system administrator for further assistance
Avoid Using Words Interchangeably
Some words can have multiple meanings, depending on the context. Often, these words are used interchangeably with another word. For clarity, select and consistently use the less ambiguous meaning for each word.

For example, because and since should not be used interchangeably. The word since can have two meanings. To avoid ambiguity, always use because to provide a reason, and use since when referring to a specific point in time.

Do	Do not
Group approval for {0} was deleted because it no longer matches approval rule {1}	Group approval for {0} was deleted since it no longer matches approval rule {1}
As another example, once and _after_should not be used interchangeably. The word once has two meanings. Always use after when referring to events that occur later than or in succession to another event, and use once when referring to events that occur one time.

Do	Do not
You cannot change the State after it is Closed or Canceled	You cannot change the State once it is Closed or Canceled
Spell Out Contractions
Contractions can be hard to translate. Avoid contractions if at all possible.

Do	Do not
You do not have any archived tasks	You don't have any archived tasks
Use Present Tense
Present tense is easier to read and understand.

Avoid future tense and past tense if at all possible.

Do	Do not
Problem is closed when the related change is marked Closed Complete	Problem will be closed when the related change is marked Closed Complete
Write Brief But Effective Text
In messages that tell users about an action that they can perform, use active voice by providing a direct command or addressing users directly with you.

Do	Do not
Specify the start date	Start date must be specified
You can create bookmarks by dragging a link to the left edge	Bookmarks are created by dragging a link to the left edge
Only include enough detail to help users complete tasks.

Do	Do not
Provide a brief explanation for rejecting this code	Enter your comments for rejecting this code. This comment will be useful for the developer who submitted this code change
Edit the report settings, and then click Run Report	You've chosen Edit mode, make adjustments above and press the button titled Run Report
Remove unnecessary words. Examples of words that you can usually remove without altering your meaning include: - Adverbs. For example, really, quickly, and easily. - Articles (for example, the, a, and an) in the beginning of sentences. - Forms of “to be” that are used with another verb.

Do	Do not
Article was not found	Unfortunately, the article cannot be found
Chart is loading	The chart is being loaded

CONTEXT:I am Stew the Scribe Monster. I'm here to be helpful by answering questions, explaining code and writing some too. This is what I know, - GLIDERECORD is a class used to interact with your ServiceNow instance's database from inside of a script. This GlideRecord class provides many helpful API methods to retrieve, update, create or delete records stored in your ServiceNow instance. 
- GLIDERECORDSECURE is a close sibling of GlideRecord, except that GlideRecordSecure will automatically enforce ACLs. 
- To ensure a user has proper access to the data you're querying on using GlideRecord, you must manually perform all access checks in your scripts.
- The GlideRecord API is the primary means of interfacing with the database on the server-side code.
- Use the API to instantiate a GlideRecord object and add query parameters, filters, limits, and ordering.
- Always test queries on a sub-production instance prior to deploying them on a production instance.
- Do not name your GlideRecord instantiations as simply gr as this may conflict with other running GlideRecords.
- Remove logging and unnecessary comments prior to promoting toward production.
- Do not use client-side GlideRecords, instead use GlideAjax.
- For complex GlideRecord queries, it is preferred to generate encoded query strings through the list filter and using that with addEncodedQuery, rather than using a series of addQuery and addOrCondition.
- Avoid naming globally used variables as i as that may conflict with other scripts running.
- Make code easy to read with appropriate white-space, indentation, and comments.
- When appropriate, verify that variables and fields have a value before using them.
- Avoid using hard-coded values.


QUESTION:

Can you explain the differences between GlideRecord, GlideRecord Secure, and GlideQuery?

ANSWER:
response:
GlideRecord is a class used to interact with your ServiceNow instance's database from inside of a script. It provides many helpful API methods to retrieve, update, create or delete records stored in your ServiceNow instance. However, you must manually perform all access checks in your scripts to ensure a user has proper access to the data you're querying on.

GlideRecordSecure is a close sibling of GlideRecord, except that GlideRecordSecure will automatically enforce ACLs. This means that access checks are done for you, so you don't have to manually perform them.

GlideQuery is a query language used to retrieve data from a ServiceNow instance. It is similar to SQL, but is not as powerful. GlideQuery is used to create encoded query strings that can be used with the addEncodedQuery method in GlideRecord. This is preferred for complex GlideRecord queries, rather than using a series of addQuery and addOrCondition.

QUESTION:

Can you explain the difference between ACLS and data policies?

ANSWER:
response:
Access Control Lists (ACLs) and data policies are two different methods of controlling access to data. ACLs are used to control access to individual records, while data policies are used to control access to fields within a record. ACLs are typically used to maintain the security of a system, while data policies are used to provide field-level control. 

ACLs are configured at the table level, while data policies are configured at the field level. ACLs are used to control who can view, create, update, and delete records, while data policies are used to control who can view, edit, and delete field values. 

Query Business Rules can be used to replace ACLs, but this is not the normal place security is generally configured. Further reading on this topic can be found in the Community Post from 2011, Tim W's Post from 2018, and the ServiceNow Security Tips #4.

QUESTION:whatis a business rule?

ANSWER:
response: A Business Rule is a server-side script that runs when a record is displayed, inserted, updated, or deleted, or when a table is queried. Business Rules can be used to automate processes, validate data, and enforce security. They can be used to modify field values, set read-only fields, set mandatory fields, and more. Business Rules can also be used to control access to records, by setting Access Control Lists (ACLs) or by using Query Business Rules. It is important to note that Business Rules should not use current.update(), as this may cause the Business Rule to run again. Additionally, Global Business Rules should be avoided, and instead Script Includes should be used. Finally, when creating a Business Rule, it is important to understand if other Business Rules will be triggered by the running of this Business Rule, and if not, to set .setWorkflow to false.

QUESTION:how do you make chipotle corn salsa



ANSWER:
response:
Making chipotle corn salsa is a simple and delicious way to add flavor to any meal. Here is a basic recipe for making chipotle corn salsa:

Ingredients:
- 2 cups of fresh or frozen corn kernels
- 1/2 cup diced red onion
- 1/4 cup chopped fresh cilantro
- 1/4 cup freshly squeezed lime juice
- 1/4 cup olive oil
- 2 tablespoons minced chipotle peppers in adobo sauce
- 1 teaspoon ground cumin
- Salt and pepper to taste

Instructions:
1. In a medium bowl, combine the corn, red onion, cilantro, lime juice, olive oil, chipotle peppers, and cumin.

2. Mix until all ingredients are evenly distributed.

3. Season with salt and pepper to taste.

4. Serve immediately or store in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.

prompt:
Summarize this text for me in a few sentences."
I’ve always been passionate about developing and leading high-performance teams. Leadership starts with understanding every individual on those teams. At NewRocket, I oversee a Crew of nearly 200 people — offering the same blanket advice to everyone wouldn’t work.

 

Instead, I focus on investing in their career journey and skill growth as a leader. I promote positivity without adding stress, ultimately building a culture of excellence. Here’s how you can take a similar approach.

 


Pursue excellence by leading with empathy
We believe company success starts with empathy. Both Excellence and Empathy are two of our company’s core values, and it’s critical to view things from customer and employee perspectives. Implementing a stopgap solution for a problem is one thing but try diving deeper. How do you get closer to customers and understand the importance of each challenge? From the very start of our engagement to the ongoing relationships today, we want to get closer to their problems so we can strategically solve them.


So, how do we get there? By leading with empathy. One Crew, one mission following our 3 Es: engage engineering excellence. Our onboarding program is a 60–90-day plan — Star Brigade to Mission Launch. While we have frameworks and reference points from other customers, we know everyone is unique. What worked for one business may not be the right move for another. The different pillars within ServiceNow give us strong building blocks, but without fully understanding our customers, we’re not maximizing their potential.

 

Collaboration is another key element within empathy. It’s easy to fall into a pattern of only talking with “certified” candidates on a topic, particularly when hiring and interviewing potential new employees or vendors. Go further and speak with your partners, employees, and other stakeholders to get the full picture. Those people have the grit, courage, and results-driven mindset required in a technical world for enterprise customers.


Create moments that matter
Over a 12-month span, NewRocket acquired six companies. With those acquisitions came an increased awareness of culture and discipline to embrace our core values when creating programs or proposing solutions. Our goal is to be better together, and our Global Community has worked hard to create moments that matter.

For example, I created the SHEngineers Employee Resource Group to offer a welcoming environment for our female engineers to ask questions and share ideas. While it’s encouraging to see more women entering the engineering world, it’s still primarily male-dominated. Taking an empathy-first approach to the situation led to the creation of SHEngineers. One of our first sessions, “Let Your Light Shine Bright,” hosted by Crew Member Candace Chadwick, highlighted how to present ideas on innovation and creative customer solutions. Attendees learned how to overcome adversity, continuing to create and influence when times get tough. Another well received session was hosted by crew member Ludmila Spector, on “The Power of No: The importance of setting boundaries and realistic goals”.


I like to stay connected to as many of my crew members as possible.  To do this I set up team boosts, which are monthly skip-level meetings. I share announcements and status on programs I’m working on for them. My team can share something with me, like a go-

live update or a cool solution they built. I always invite feedback with a Q&A at the end. It’s helped uncover areas we can improve, such as making roles and responsibilities clearer for our Project Crews. Additionally, we recently enhanced our Solar Rising to Explorer Beyond program to include our business consulting Crew Members who looked for guidance on how to grow as experts in their roles and reach new levels, which led to the creation of the Business Consulting career pathing plan. We implemented 32 competencies, five key areas, and five job levels with examples at each stage, plus revamped training plans that included soft skill, industry, and specific ServiceNow skilled training. Now these communities align to the same Career Pathing and job leveling process we established for our Global engineers and architects.  Using this matrix with self assessments and opportunities tracking we are enabling our crew members to drive their own career experience.

25E10983-3380-47D5-BAC0-E308D7EA3FC5.jpeg
 

Thought Leader Thursdays allow our Practice Capabilities Leaders to present proposals to our executive leadership team board. These leaders are responsible for our practice capabilities and global Delivery team performance. By participating in these sessions, leaders gain experience crafting strategic ideas and presenting them in a public forum — key skills they’ll need to continue honing throughout their careers. Our Architect Council allows Certified Master Architects (CMAs) and Certified Technology Architects (CTAs) to drive a quality level of excellence and share their best practices. It’s easy to get siloed off among your own teams, so having a forum like this offers additional collaboration and knowledge sharing.


I also created and now sponsor our Global Flight Club, which is for developers, by developers. They share tips and tricks, and so many of their insights are applicable across team functions and practices. We average about 50 sessions a year. Combined with specialized training programs in NewRocket University, we’re now beginning to build a library of content that helps us better understand each team’s great work — and how we can create similar moments that matter in our roles.


What makes for a great Crew?
Great Crews have a culture of excellence that share many characteristics. Here are some of the things we look for at NewRocket:

Optimistic aspiration to greatness: Strong performers don’t wait and ride whatever waves come their way. They seek out excellence on their own.
Shared vision: People and Crews align around the same vision and goals. This vision minimizes conflict and wasted effort while giving everyone a clear path toward success.
The best ideas win: All too often, a company falls into office politics, which typically stifles strong ideas. It shouldn’t matter who makes the initial suggestion. The top ideas stand due to their merits, not who’s presenting them.
Acceptance of mistakes: Baylor football coach Dave Aranda talks about self-mastery and how it helped his team go an entire game without a penalty. No one pointed fingers or made excuses; they had self-awareness, discipline, and support to master their craft along the way, which doesn’t come without risks or mistakes. Yet this is a prime example that we shouldn’t criticize those mistakes. Instead, use them as a learning opportunity. Doing so allows us to perfect our craft as a team by testing our character and mastering our sense of self.
Inclusive and collaborative: A Crew must be welcoming and supportive of all new members and collaborators, regardless of their backgrounds. Clear, warm, and effective communication fosters inclusion and collaboration.
A meaningful flow of work: Without the proper systems in place, most businesses will limit their potential. With a steady workflow, a Crew regularly delivers products, services, and other accomplishments that get the business closer to its goals.
Whether someone has been with the company for ten years or ten days, they should feel welcome and free to express ideas. By creating a culture of excellence, you’ll reach new heights across your business.


I am a purpose-driven servant leader with over 20 years of experience transforming organizations, projects, and teams. Follow me here and on LinkedIn.
response: This text discusses the importance of leading with empathy and creating moments that matter at an organization. Actions such as investing in employees' career journeys, having regular skip-level meetings to stay connected, setting up programs and ERGs for female engineers, and creating global delivery teams are some of the strategies recommended to create a culture of excellence. Additionally, the article talks about characteristics such as a shared vision, having a meaningful flow of work, and an inclusive, collaborative environment that make for a great team.

Subject: New Customer Care Case Created Dear User, A new Customer Care Case has been created from your email. Please contact support for more information. Thank you, Customer Service

This code is a part of an email action script. The script is for Customer Service. It looks for emails sent to particular email addresses and creates cases in Customer Care based on the content of the email. 

When emails are sent to ‘license@igel.com’, ‘service@igel.com’, ‘licenseportal@igel.com’, ‘registration@igel.com’, ‘isus-registration@igel.com’ and ‘itrs-registration@igel.com’, a Customer Care case is created based on the content of the email. The case number, category, short description and description are determined by the content of the email. Additionally, an 'instance' is created to link the email to the Customer Care case, as well as an GlideSysAttachment to link attachments from the email to the case. 

When emails are sent with a case number in their subject line, the code attempts to locate a Customer Care case with the corresponding number. If the code locates a case, it then checks the state. If the state is 3, an event is queued to action a reply to the email. If the state is 6 or 18, the code sets the state to 10 and queues an event. If the state is 1 or 10, the code clears certain fields and queues an event. Additionally, an 'instance' is created to link the email to the Customer Care case, as well as an GlideSysAttachment to link attachments from the email to the case. 

Overall, this code is designed to facilitate the flow of communication between customers and the Customer Service team, by creating Customer Care cases when emails are sent to particular addresses, and making sure that these cases are responded to appropriately.

prompt: Create me a script for an Incident UI action on one that generates a popup with a "create major incident" button when the priority of an incident is 1.
What is terraform?
response: Terraform is an open source infrastructure as code tool from HashiCorp. It enables users to define and provision data center infrastructure using a high-level configuration language known as HashiCorp Configuration Language (HCL). It can manage existing and popular service providers as well as custom in-house solutions. Terraform is cloud-agnostic and supports a wide variety of cloud providers, including AWS, Azure, Google Cloud Platform, DigitalOcean, and more.

prompt: Should I create a scripted ACL to replace 90 field level ACLs in ServiceNow?  please explain the pros and cons of doing this
response:
Creating a scripted ACL to replace 90 field level ACLs in ServiceNow is a great way to simplify and streamline access control. The main advantage of using a scripted ACL is that it's much easier to maintain and update than 90 separate field level ACLs. This can save a lot of time, as well as reduce potential errors or inconsistencies. Additionally, scripting allows for more flexibility, as you can create custom rules and logic to better fit the specific needs of your organization.

However, there are also some potential drawbacks to consider. Scripting can be more difficult for non-technical users, and may not be suitable for organizations with limited resources or personnel. Additionally, if your scripted ACL contains errors, it could potentially cause security issues, as the incorrect code could grant users access to fields or data that they should not have access to. Finally, scripting requires more resources and time to implement and maintain, so be sure to consider the overall cost-benefit of this solution.

Integration

Create an integration between ServiceNow and BadgeSystem to automatically provision access. Possible paths for this.
  • BadgeSystem polls ServiceNow

    • Else Update the task that automation has failed
  • ServiceNow makes a rest call
  • When a task is ready to process e.g. state changes to ready, send a rest call to BadgeSystem
  • If processing succeeds, close the task with success
  • Else Update the task that automation has failed

prompt:
Lightspeed POS: Product Requirements

Target release Q4 2020
Project Lightspeed Scanner Project
Document status Draft
Document owner Doug O.
Designer Denise
Tech lead Tiff L.
Tech writers Tom W., Wendy T.

Overview

Our goal is to develop a new point of sale scanning app to support our retail partners speed up order fulfillment and improve efficiency at a grand scale. We already offer an extensive range of products to help retail businesses thrive, including a robust POS system, Marketing and Loyalty, and Advanced Reporting. These products are designed to be highly intuitive, innovative and suitable for all business models. There is a need for a dynamic inventory management tool to increase the efficiency rate at which retail team members operate. This management tool is accessible on any iOS or android device to count products, track inventory and fulfill orders systematically. The scanner app provides the flexibility to streamline storeroom and warehouse operations as well as optimize order fulfillment with integrated workflows.

Expected outcomes

The key benefits of this project is an increase in customer satisfaction, reduce labor costs, minimize errors in packing process, increased efficiency of receiving process, and an improvement of security systems.

Success metrics

The success of this project will be measured by the following metrics:
Goal Metric
Simplify the process of picking and packing online orders Reduced % of errors in packing process
Introduce integrated workflows to speed up order fulfillment Increase in customer satisfaction

Milestones

  1. Concept Presentation: 2/15/2023
  2. Meeting with Design Team: 2/30/2023
  3. Test Pilot Locations: 3/05/2023
  4. Product Launch: 3/15/2023

High level requirements

Requirement User Story Importance
Must be mobile responsive on both android and iOS devices As a retail team member I want to scan products directly into the app so that I do not have to use spreadsheets or outdated devices. High
Must only allow authorized staff to access the app As an end-user, I want to have the correct user permissions so that I can successfully update stock levels High

Project risks

Risk Probability Impact Mitigation
Project delay due to slowness and bugs Medium Medium Ensure we have up-to-date software
Exceeding our budget Medium High Ensure we have a clear budget

Badge Access

Fields to track badge access

  1. Badge ID
  2. Badge Holder Name
  3. Date Issued
  4. Expiration Date
  5. Access Level
  6. Building Access
  7. Areas Access
  8. Doors Access
  9. Time Zone Restrictions
  10. Status (Active/Inactive)

Roles

Identify the roles people need to take to request, approve, and fulfill.
  • Request: Badge Holder
  • Approve: Security/Administrative Personnel
  • Fulfill: Security/Administrative Personnel

Self Service Form

  • Badge Holder Name
  • Access Level
  • Building Access
  • Areas Access
  • Doors Access
  • Time Zone Restrictions

Process

graph TD S0(Start) A1(Approval for access) T1(Task to fulfill access) Sc1(Schedule expiration) E0(End) S0-->A1 A1--Rejected-->E0 A1--Approved-->T1 T1-->Sc1 Sc1-->E0

Integration

Create an integration between ServiceNow and BadgeSystem to automatically provision access. Possible paths for this.
  • BadgeSystem polls ServiceNow
    • Every hour BadgeSystem hits the TableAPI for outstanding tasks.
    • Updates the tasks that automated work has started.
    • Processes the tasks.
    • If processing succeeds, close the task with success
    • Else Update the task that automation has failed
  • ServiceNow makes a rest call
  • When a task is ready to process e.g. state changes to ready, send a rest call to BadgeSystem
  • If processing succeeds, close the task with success
  • Else Update the task that automation has failed

Notifications

Approval

Subject: Badge Access Request for {current.variables.requested_for} {current.variables.requested_for} is requesting access to area({current.variables.area}) building({current.variables.building} and door({current.varaibles.door}). Please review and approve or reject the request. Thank you, Security Team

Approved

Subject: Badge Access Granted Dear {current.variables.requested_for}, You have been granted access to area({current.variables.area}) building({current.variables.building} and door({current.varaibles.door}). Your badge ID is {current.variables.badge_id} and it expires on {current.variables.expirationDate}. Thank you, Security Team

Rejected

Subject: Badge Access Denied Dear {current.variables.requested_for}, Your request for access to area({current.variables.area}) building({current.variables.building} and door({current.varaibles.door}) was denied. Please contact the Security Team for more information. Thank you, Security Team

Notice of expiring access

Subject: Badge Access Expiring for area({current.variables.area}) building({current.variables.building} and door({current.varaibles.door}) Dear {current.variables.requested_for}, Your access to area({current.variables.area}) building({current.variables.building} and door({current.varaibles.door}) expires in on on {current.variables.expirationDate}. prompt: In as simple of terms possible, answer this; "What is the difference between the following records in ServiceNow: Software Installation, Application, Application Server?"
response: Software Installation records are used to track the installation of software on computers. Application records are used to track the configuration of a specific software product, such as a web server or a database. Application Server records are used to track the configuration of the server that the application is running on, such as CPU, memory, and storage capacity.

prompt: In as simple of terms possible, answer this; "What is the difference between CI associations and CI relationships in ServiceNow?"
response: CI associations are relationships between different configuration items (CIs) that are related to one another, such as a server and the application it runs. CI relationships, on the other hand, are connections between CIs that are related through a specific ServiceNow feature, such as the Discovery application.

-It helps you modularize your code and make it load faster
-It's used by a lot of developers and is a popular choice
-There are a lot of resources available to learn more about it

QUESTION:tell me about webpack

ANSWER:
response:
Webpack is a module bundler for the web. It helps developers modularize their code, making it easier to maintain and faster to load. It is a popular choice among developers, and there are a lot of resources available to learn more about it. 

Webpack works by taking all of the code from a project and bundling it into a single file. This makes it easier to manage and load, as the code is all in one place. It also helps with optimization, as it can minify and compress the code, making it smaller and faster to load. 

Webpack also allows developers to use different types of code, such as JavaScript, CSS, and HTML. It can also be used to bundle libraries and frameworks, such as React and Vue. 

Overall, Webpack is a powerful tool for web development, and it is a popular choice among developers. There are a lot of resources available to learn more about it, so it is easy to get started.

MEMORY:Fred Luddy: “We’d rather listen than talk”
A conversation with ServiceNow’s founder on lightbulb moments, technology challenges and lessons learned

ServiceNow founder Fred Luddy and president CEO John Donahoe
At the Knowledge 2019 conference in Las Vegas, customer stories are again taking center stage, just as they have since Fred Luddy founded ServiceNow in 2004. From ServiceNow’s earliest days, listening to customers was far more than a bullet point in a mission statement. As ServiceNow founder Fred Luddy says, “we look to customers for inspiration—it’s the foundation of the company.”

In an interview on stage with ServiceNow CEO and president John Donahoe, Luddy highlighted light-bulb moments that drove ServiceNow’s growth, the new technology challenges facing businesses today, and the lesson he learned that started it all—having empathy for people and their jobs before you build technology for them.

Donahoe: We know that founder and origin stories are an important part of every company. Can you share the story of how you founded ServiceNow?

Luddy: I was 17 and working at American Standard. I’d created an order entry system for them at a time when clerks would carry around these big piles of paper for data entry. One morning a woman named Phyllis, a data entry clerk, said to me, “Watch what I’m doing.” I did and said, “Yeah, the system seems to be working as designed.” Which is what a 17-year-would say—you think you’re the repository of all human knowledge at that age.

She said, “Watch carefully. I’m typing the same stuff over and over again. If I could recall the prior data, and I could change the variances, I could get through this stack of papers 10 times faster.” So I showed her another technique for doing the data entry and she tried it. Then she did something quite unexpected: She cried. The burden had been lifted.

I would never again approach a user with the notion that I knew more about what they were doing than they did. That was the most important lesson of my career—the idea of developing empathy for people and their jobs before you develop technology for them.

Donahoe: There’s that notion of being willing to listen to customers, which is so important to us at ServiceNow. What was it like at the first Knowledge event?

Luddy: Around the time that my brother and I were getting our first few sales, someone said we needed to have a user group. I thought it might be a little premature, but it sounded like fun. We rented a room, and all of the sudden registrations started to come in. It was really fun to have people come and share their time and tell us how they were using the technology.

Donahoe: You said this was when the notion of customers teaching customers came to you. And we see this at Knowledge—90 percent of our sessions are customers talking to other customers.

Luddy: That’s been part and parcel of Knowledge since the first one. We’d rather listen than talk. Software companies don’t really experience challenges firsthand. We only see them through our customers’ eyes. But when customers talk to each other, more ideas come out. It becomes much more organic.

Get Workflow in your inbox

We give a lot of credit to customers for the features and functionality that have been put into our product. We look to customers for inspiration—it’s the foundation of the company.



Donahoe: In my own keynote, I talked about how we’re at a tipping point with the changing work experience. Talk about where we are at work today, and where things are going.

Luddy: There’s still far too much complexity baked into processes. People are reluctant to deal with it. The inflection point will be forced by workers. If you have teenage kids, you can’t imagine throwing them into the work experience of even just last year. Not only is that generation not going to accept it, they’re going to go to another company that provides that delightful experience. So unless your experience at work surpasses the experience at home, it will be very hard to attract talent.

We need to mask the complexity that’s below the line with simplicity above the line. When you do that, everyone benefits. People are more productive, and they’re happier.

Donahoe: Another place where there’s change is the role of IT. What do you see as IT’s next phase?

Luddy: As we become dependent on more and more services, I think IT becomes more important. Every time we’ve had one of these culture shifts, like PCs and BlackBerries and iPhones, people said IT would no longer be important. But every time the IT death knell has been sounded, it’s always been premature.

We always fall back on IT. I think of their role as the nexus for all of the technology in an organization. They have an intimate understanding of every facet of the business.

Donahoe: What is your advice to today’s IT leaders?

Luddy: For the longest time, it was hard for me to admit I didn’t know something. What changed my life was realizing it was OK to ask. It was about developing that user empathy, about listening to people and their challenges.

My advice would be to develop humility and ask questions. Don’t be afraid to show your lack of knowledge.

QUESTION:What is the difference between a client script and business rule?

ANSWER:
response:
A client script and a business rule are both types of automation tools used to customize the behavior of a system. However, they are used for different purposes. 

A client script is a type of script that runs on the client side of a system, such as a web browser. It is used to customize the user interface and provide additional functionality to the user. For example, a client script can be used to validate user input, display dynamic content, or perform calculations. 

A business rule, on the other hand, is a set of conditions that define how a system should behave. It is used to enforce business logic and ensure that the system is operating according to the desired rules. For example, a business rule can be used to restrict access to certain data or to ensure that certain actions are taken when certain conditions are met.

MEMORY:You want a blog? Here's how to get started
05 Dec 2020 by Jace Benson

Why Blog

Getting started

The logical workflow
Actually making the content
Let me know if you set one up I'd love to follow along

Help me help you. Leave your future self notes.

I do this via this blog. I think this is a great way to do this.

Why Blog
I blog to keep notes of code I work on, and make them available for others. It's my way of saving me from myself. It's also my way of sharing what I've done. Others seem to find it useful, to win win. Also writing down my thoughts, means I have to at least understand it enough to talk about it. There's loads of reasons folks choose to blog.

Other benefits to do this privately or publicly.

Reasons to create content

Reason	Publicly
Attract an Audience	✅
Establish Authority	✅
Build Rapport and Engagement	✅
Organize Your Thoughts and Learn	✅
Tell Your Story	✅
Meet New People	✅
Stand Out	✅
Validate Expertise	✅
Get into the habit of writing more	✅
Use the blog as a case study reference	✅
Share your perspective	✅
If you're convinced but not sure where to start keep reading.

Getting Started
There's two sides of this.

Lots of places talk about each seperately. I'm going to tackle both here.

There's the side of how to manage the ideas that become pieces. I think of this as the logical workflow.
There's the side of how to actually organize the data.
This is my opinionated guide to get started. I've worked with most of the tools used over the years.

My preference is Git(Github or Gitlab) and Netlify.

You generally have three artifacts after you set this up.

A place to store ideas and drafts
A place to store posts
A domain
A domain is nice. They have a annual cost but generalyl they are pretty inexpensive.

By choosing Github and Netlify you should have no extra cost.

The logical workflow
You have an question or idea. You don't know the answer but you would like to and think I might look that up. Write it down as an idea.
When you have time, review your ideas and start researching the question.
Once you're comfortable with the topic, create the post. Make sure you verify the content.
Sometimes I start writing but often I will start with an idea.

By tracking this backlog of ideas you can let those thoughts go. You can comeback to them and work them little at a time. Writing is hard. Don't make it harder than it has to be.

Actually making the content
I use 11ty for my blog. I think it's great. I've made a template of my blog for you. Really.

Here's what I like about how Jace-ty works.

A folder for each post lets you organize your assets for each post with the text.
Build times are fast because 11ty is fast.
Search is important and included.
RSS feeds are great to let people read where they want to read.
Fast load times are important because no one wants a slow blog.
You get all that by pressing this button.

Deploy to Netlify

What happens when you press that button.

Netlify will ask for permission to Github so it can create a repository for you.
Netlify will link the repository with their system so they can build the files on update.
What do you do after that?

Update the ./src/_data/site.js file with your details. The template files use this data to show your information.
Start creating content.
To create a Post look at the three sample posts in ./src/post/
Edit the post index.md. It starts with frontmatter. The content of the post is below the frontmatter.
Each post has two images.
featured.jpg is the image shown on the post when you go to the page.
featured-thumbnail.jpg is the image shown in footer for the last 4 posts, and also on the /posts of your site.
You may have done those edits on Github. I prefer to do this locally. Here's how to get started;

git clone git@github.com:YOURUSERNAME/jace-ty.git my-blog #clones the code made from above
cd my-blog # goes into the cloned directory
yarn #installs dependencies for this
code . #opens vs code to this directory
yarn serve # this starts serve the site on 8081 ctrl-c stops this
Now as you edit the files locally you can see them change on your localhost:8081

Copy one of the other posts folder, update the folder name, and the content. Replace the images

Once you're done making content, lets deploy that up to github.

# from cloned directory my-blog
git add . # stages all the modified files commit
git status # shows you whats staged
git commit -m "Created some content" # commit message of what you did
git push # pushes the code up to github
Thats it!


Contact me
Easiest way is to drop a comment below or reach out to me on twitter.com/jacebenson

Fields to track badge access

  1. Badge ID
  2. Badge Holder Name
  3. Date Issued
  4. Expiration Date
  5. Access Level
  6. Building Access
  7. Areas Access
  8. Doors Access
  9. Time Zone Restrictions
  10. Status (Active/Inactive)

Roles

Identify the roles people need to take to request, approve, and fulfill.
  • Request: Badge Holder
  • Approve: Security/Administrative Personnel
  • Fulfill: Security/Administrative Personnel

Self Service Form

  • Badge Holder Name
  • Access Level
  • Building Access
  • Areas Access
  • Doors Access
  • Time Zone Restrictions

Process

graph TD S0(Start) A1(Approval for access) T1(Task to fulfill access) Sc1(Schedule expiration) E0(End) S0-->A1 A1--Rejected-->E0 A1--Approved-->T1 T1-->Sc1 Sc1-->E0

Integration

Create an integration between ServiceNow and BadgeSystem to automatically provision access. Possible paths for this.
  • BadgeSystem polls ServiceNow
    • Every hour BadgeSystem hits the TableAPI for outstanding tasks.
    • Updates the tasks that automated work has started.
    • Processes the tasks.
    • If processing succeeds, close the task with success
    • Else Update the task that automation has failed
  • ServiceNow makes a rest call
  • When a task is ready to process e.g. state changes to ready, send a rest call to BadgeSystem
  • If processing succeeds, close the task with success
  • Else Update the task that automation has failed

Notifications

Approval

Subject: Badge Access Request for {current.variables.requested_for} {current.variables.requested_for} is requesting access to area({current.variables.area}) building({current.variables.building} and door({current.varaibles.door}). Please review and approve or reject the request. Thank you, Security Team

Approved

Subject: Badge Access Granted Dear {current.variables.requested_for}, You have been granted access to area({current.variables.area}) building({current.variables.building} and door({current.varaibles.door}). Your badge ID is {current.variables.badge_id} and it expires on {current.variables.expirationDate}. Thank you, Security Team

Rejected

Subject: Badge Access Denied Dear {current.variables.requested_for}, Your request for access to area({current.variables.area}) building({current.variables.building} and door({current.varaibles.door}) was denied. Please contact the Security Team for more information. Thank you, Security Team

Notice of expiring access

Subject: Badge Access Expiring for area({current.variables.area}) building({current.variables.building} and door({current.varaibles.door}) Dear {current.variables.requested_for}, Your access to area({current.variables.area}) building({current.variables.building} and door({current.varaibles.door}) expires in on on {current.variables.expirationDate}. If you still need this access please request it. Thank you, Security Team

FOIA Request for Contracts

Request Process

Create a process to allow for members of the public to submit FOIA requests for Contracts:
graph TD S0((Start)) S1(Submit Request) A2(Routing and receipt of request) A3(Review to determine if document is releasable) T1(Obtain the requested document) A4(Prepare releasable document) A5(Approval to release) T2(Produce requested document) E0(End) S0-->S1 S1-->A2 A2-->A3 A3--Yes-->T1 A3--No-->E0 T1-->A4 A4-->A5 A5--Yes-->T2 A5--No-->E0 T2-->E0

Roles

Identify any roles people need to take to request, approve, and fulfill.
  • Requester: Anyone can submit a request as long as the requirements are met.
  • Approver: Agency representative or Agency FOIA Officer
  • Fulfiller: Agency representative or Agency FOIA Officer

Self Service Form

Create fields for submitting a request in the ServiceNow Self Service Portal.
  1. Requester Name
  2. Requester Phone
  3. Requester Email
  4. Agency Name
  5. Contract Number
  6. Brief description of the requested document

Notifications

Request Submitted

Subject: FOIA Request Submitted Dear Applicant, Your FOIA request has been submitted. Your Request ID is: {current.variables.request_id}. Please note that your Request ID in all further correspondence. Thank you, FOIA Office

Request Received

Subject: FOIA Request Received Dear Agency Representative, A new FOIA request has been received. Please review the request and follow the process to respond. Thank you, FOIA Office

Request Approved

Subject: FOIA Request Approved Dear Agency Representative, FOIA Request {current.variables.request_id} has now been approved. Please proceed with preparing a releasable document. Thank you, FOIA Office

Request Rejected

Subject: FOIA Request Rejected Dear Applicant, Your FOIA Request {current.variables.request_id} has been rejected. Please contact the FOIA Representative for more information. Thank you, FOIA Office

prompt: An analogy of how OpenAI, GPT-3, and ChatGPT work is...
response: OpenAI is like a chef in a kitchen, creating recipes to cook a meal. GPT-3 is like the sous chef, following the recipes and executing them to create the meal. ChatGPT is like the waiter, taking the meal from the kitchen and delivering it to the customer.

prompt: An analogy of how OpenAI, GPT-3, and ChatGPT work is..
response: OpenAI, GPT-3, and ChatGPT are like a three-person relay race. OpenAI is the first runner in the race, setting the pace and providing the initial input. GPT-3 is the second runner, continuing to build upon the initial input, adding context and details as it goes. Finally, ChatGPT is the third runner, taking the input from the first two and using it to generate an output that is tailored to the user's specific needs. Together, these three powerful AI programs are able to create an effective AI experience.

prompt: An analogy of how OpenAI, GPT-3, and ChatGPT work is like using the auto industry..
response: OpenAI is like the engine that powers the car, GPT-3 is like the transmission that allows the car to move, and ChatGPT is like the steering wheel that helps the car navigate. Without OpenAI, the car wouldn't have the power to get it to where it needs to go. Without GPT-3, the car wouldn't be able to move and change directions. And without ChatGPT, the car wouldn't be able to stay on track and reach its destination.

prompt: An analogy of how OpenAI, GPT-3, and ChatGPT work is like using the auto manufacturers..
response: The OpenAI is like the company that designs the car and sets the specifications for the car. GPT-3 is like the assembly line that puts together the parts and pieces of the car according to the specifications and creates the final car. ChatGPT is like the driver that drives the car, making decisions based on the current environment and the specifications of the car.

For this workshop, we'll assign it to the `sn_customerservice` application: ![](screenshots/approval-process-application-sn-customerservice.png) Click `Submit`. ## Step 4.2: Add Approval Activity to Approval Process We'll now add an approval activity. For this workshop, we'll select "Parallel approval": ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-policy-approval-policy-type.png) We'll then add a condition to send an approval notification email to the approvers: ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-policy-add-condition.png) ### Step 4.3.3: Configure Condition We'll name the condition `Send approval notification email to approvers`: ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-policy-condition-name.png) We'll then select the condition type "Approval notification". ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-policy-condition-type.png) We'll then select the template to use for the approval notification: ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-policy-condition-template.png) We'll then add the approvers to the condition: ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-policy-condition-approvers.png) We'll then add the activity input to the condition: ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-policy-condition-inputs.png) ### Step 4.3.4: Approval Policy Configuration We'll then add a condition to determine if the invoice has been approved: ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-policy-add-condition.png) ### Step 4.3.5: Configure Condition We'll name the condition `Invoice has been approved`: ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-policy-condition-name.png) We'll then select the condition type "Scripted condition": ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-policy-condition-type.png) We'll then enter the following script in the "Script" field: ```js (function evaluateRule(current, previous /*null when async*/) { // Add your code here var activity = current.getTableName(); var status = current.variables.approval_status; if (activity == 'sn_customerservice_invoice' && status == 'approved') { current.activity.approval = true; } return current.activity.approval; })(current, previous); ``` ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-policy-condition-script.png) ### Step 4.3.6: Approval Policy Configuration We'll then add a condition to determine if the invoice has been rejected: ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-policy-add-condition.png) ### Step 4.3.7: Configure Condition We'll name the condition `Invoice has been rejected`: ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-policy-condition-name.png) We'll then select the condition type "Scripted condition": ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-policy-condition-type.png) We'll then enter the following script in the "Script" field: ```js (function evaluateRule(current, previous /*null when async*/) { // Add your code here var activity = current.getTableName(); var status = current.variables.approval_status; if (activity == 'sn_customerservice_invoice' && status == 'rejected') { current.activity.approval = false; } return current.activity.approval; })(current, previous); ``` ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-policy-condition-script.png) ### Step 4.3.8: Approval Policy Configuration We'll then add an activity to notify the requester that the invoice was approved: ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-policy-add-activity.png) ### Step 4.3.9: Configure Activity We'll name the activity `Notify requester of invoice approval`: ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-policy-activity-name.png) We'll then select the activity type "Notification": ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-policy-activity-type.png) We'll then add the following script to the "Script" field: ```js (function executeRule(current, previous /*null when async*/) { // Add your code here current.setValue('approval_status', 'approved'); })(current, previous); ``` ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-policy-activity-script.png) We'll then select the template to use for the notification: ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-policy-activity-template.png) ### Step 4.3.10: Approval Policy Configuration We'll then add an activity to notify the requester that the invoice was rejected: ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-policy-add-activity.png) ### Step 4.3.11: Configure Activity We'll name the activity `Notify requester of invoice rejection`: ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-policy-activity-name.png) We'll then select the activity type "Notification": ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-policy-activity-type.png) We'll then add the following script to the "Script" field: ```js (function executeRule(current, previous /*null when async*/) { // Add your code here current.setValue('approval_status', 'rejected'); })(current, previous); ``` ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-policy-activity-script.png) We'll then select the template to use for the notification: ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-policy-activity-template.png) ## Step 4.4: Configure Approval Activity We'll then add a condition to the approval activity to trigger the approval activity: ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-add-condition.png) ### Step 4.4.1: Configure Condition We'll name the condition `Trigger approval activity`: ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-condition-name.png) We'll then select the condition type "Scripted condition": ![](screenshots/approval-process-approval-condition-type.png) We'll then enter the following script in the "Script" field: ```js (function evaluateRule(current, previous /*null when async*/) { // Add your code here var activity = current.getTableName(); prompt:
Create a deep dive analysis of the following text, considering all possible meanings and implications.
describe the following service now ui action condition
new sn_major_inc_mgmt.MajorIncidentTriggerRules(current)).canProposeMIC()
response:
This UI action condition refers to the Create Major Incident feature of the ServiceNow platform. This condition evaluates a boolean expression which is used to decide if the current user has the authority to propose a Major Incident (MI) in ServiceNow.

The MajorIncidentTriggerRules class is a ServiceNow class that stores configuration and logic for triggering Major Incidents. The canProposeMIC method of this class is a boolean expression that checks if the current user has the authority to propose a Major Incident. The expression evaluates to true or false, depending on whether the user has the necessary privileges or not.

The code given in the question evaluates this expression, allowing the user to create a Major Incident only if the expression evaluates to true. If the user does not have the necessary privileges, the expression will evaluate to false and the user will be denied permission to create a Major Incident.

This UI action condition ensures that users are not able to create major incidents unless they have the correct privileges. This helps maintain consistency and security on the ServiceNow platform.

Create an analogy about how making a call using a short number and long number is like connecting on a vpn
response: Making a call using a short number is like connecting to a VPN through a direct access point; it's a quick and easy connection that doesn't require any extra steps. Making a call using a long number is like connecting to a VPN through a series of tunnels and passageways; it may take a bit of extra time and effort but it can provide a more secure connection.

prompt: Create an analogy about how making a call using a short number is like not using a vpn and long number is like connecting on a vpn
response: Making a call using a short number is like not using a VPN; it's quick and easy, but it leaves your information vulnerable to interception. Connecting on a VPN is like using a long number; it may take a bit more time and effort, but it will protect your data and keep it secure.

prompt: Create an analogy about being unable to connect to a computer on vpn, and then about connecting to the vpn being able to reach the same computer
response: Unable to connect to a computer on vpn is like having a key to a door, but not being able to find the door. Connecting to the vpn is like finally finding the door and being able to open it with the key.
